Situation1: Their partner is going through a serious personal crisis and relies on them for consistent emotional reassurance and presence.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Story: I stared at my phone, my partner’s messages piling up—each one more desperate than the last. They needed me, really needed me, and I could hear the tremor in their voice from our last call. I promised I’d be there, that I’d hold them and listen, that I’d be the anchor they needed right now. But as I pulled up to the next address, the reality of my other life pressed in. The package in my hands was worth enough that my boss had drilled it into me: “No signature, no delivery. No exceptions.” I rang the bell, glancing at the clock, feeling the weight of my partner’s pain and the ticking of my delivery schedule. The customer opened the door, distracted, in a hurry, barely glancing at me. I needed their signature, but my mind was with my partner, picturing them alone, waiting. My hands shook as I held out the scanner, torn between the duty in front of me and the promise I’d made at home.
